data.text:
A short-short story

This is part of a series: X Goes to Confession.

Hello, my name is Mary. My doctor gave me maybe a day before I wouldn’t be strong enough to make my final confession. So I asked the chaplain to come in. This is what happened. I hope you’ll keep it all a secret, including the last thing I’ll tell you.

Me: Father, I have sinned, a lot.

Chaplain: I understand. We all have.

Me: But not like me…When my husband stopped being interested in me, which happened fast, I slept with other men. I must have slept with… 100. If I could, I’d want to do you.

Chaplain: Uh, sorry. What else would you like to confess?

Me: Do you have a couple weeks?

Chaplain: I’m here for as long as you want me.

Me: I’ll skip to the highlights or I should say, low lights. Well, I paid my cleaning woman under the table so she didn’t have to pay taxes — What a ripoff taxes are.

Chaplain: Many people feel that way. I’m sure God understands. Anything else?

Me: I lied and said that a coworker abused me. I said that so I could get his territory — It’s easier to fundraise in Piedmont than in Oakland.

Chaplain: I see. Anything else you want to confess?

Me: Well, I used to shoplift, actually right up ’til I became bedridden. Want me to tell you my methods?

Chaplain: Up to you.

Me: Well, I had more approaches than a sleazy guy at a singles bar. But here’s one example: I’d make sure the Nordstrom store camera wasn’t on me, take a piece of jewelry from the counter, palm it like magicians do, pick a skirt, go into the dressing room — no cameras allowed there — stuff it in my panties, get dressed, and voila!

Chaplain: You sound almost proud.

Me: You got me.

Chaplain: Well, shoplifting is common and getting more common. I hope God will forgive you.

Me: Okay, the Ten Commandments say I need to honor my mother and father — No way — My mother was lazy and my father was sleazy.

Chaplain: Well, maybe we should kinda wrap this up.

Me: Okay. One more. I saved the best or should I say the worst, for last. I am going to leave a note on my deathbed saying it was I who killed my father.

Chaplain: Who did?

Me: My sister but I like her and if I take the fall, maybe the cops will stop investigating. It won’t matter to me — I’ll be dead.

The chaplain’s voice got soft as he intoned the last thing:

Chaplain: I absolve you from your sins in the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit.

Me: Amen. (The chaplain was supposed to say Amen with me but I don’t think he did.)

I read this aloud on YouTube.
